GREEN_EFA applauds the inclusion of mandatory staffing provisions for tax authorities, recognizing this as essential to operationalize data-sharing mechanisms and close loopholes in digital transaction monitoring.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the urgent need to extend VAT reforms to the aviation sector’s exemption, proposing this as a critical next step to align fiscal policy with climate goals under the Green Deal.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue’s role in advancing environmental justice by redirecting recovered VAT revenues toward sustainable public investments, consistent with COP21 priorities.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the importance of ongoing parliamentary oversight to ensure member states implement fraud prevention measures without diluting transparency standards.

ECR strongly approves the issue's focus on combating VAT fraud through enhanced data-sharing mechanisms, aligning with ECR's commitment to fiscal responsibility and cross-border law enforcement efficiency.  
ECR approves the CESOP system's implementation as critical for tracking e-commerce transactions, while proposing collaboration with the European Data Protection Supervisor to ensure proportionality in data collection under Article 24c.  
ECR emphasizes the need for objective analysis of VAT gap disparities between member states, urging the Commission to incorporate comparative performance metrics in Recital 2b to identify best practices.  
ECR applauds provisions allowing swift action against non-EU sellers, highlighting Poland's proven success in reducing VAT fraud through similar verification frameworks as a model for Article 12a implementation.  
ECR recommends periodic review clauses in Article 37 to assess the administrative burden on businesses, ensuring compliance mechanisms remain targeted rather than broadly disruptive.

ID rejects the issue’s expanded surveillance frameworks (Articles 12a, 24c) as a violation of national sovereignty, firmly doubting with ID’s commitment to subsidiarity and fiscal autonomy.  
The proposal’s administrative overreach overlooks critical aspects such as reducing excessive VAT burdens, which ID identifies as the root cause of fraud and economic stagnation.  
ID opposes the erosion of unanimous tax decision-making under Article 293(2) TFEU, which undermines member states’ democratic control over fiscal policies.  
The issue’s data-sharing mandates (Articles 36, 37) are inconsistent with ID’s principles of limited EU intervention, prioritizing bureaucratic control over citizen-centric reforms.  
ID condemns leveraging VAT enforcement to fund ideological agendas, failing to align with public demands for fiscal restraint and tangible welfare improvements.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by approving the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0813) as amended, introducing amendments to Regulation (EU) No 904/2010 that include adding new recitals (2a, 2b, 2c) and articles (e.g., Articles 12a, 24c, 24d, 36, 37, 49a, 50), and modifying existing provisions in Recitals 8, 11, 13, 14, 18, and other sections to strengthen administrative cooperation frameworks. The resolution mandates the Commission to revise its proposal in accordance with these amendments under Article 293(2) TFEU, emphasizes the Council’s obligation to inform Parliament of any deviations from the approved text, and requires renewed consultation if the Council proposes substantial changes. It further instructs the Parliament’s President to communicate the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment in the implementation of enhanced compliance and data-sharing mechanisms across member states.

title: Minimum level of taxation for multinational groups: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive on ensuring a global minimum level of taxation for multinational groups in the Union | A9-0140/2022 | European Parliament
background: The OECD/G20 Inclusive Framework’s October 2021 agreement established a 15% global minimum corporate tax rate, supported by 137 jurisdictions, to address profit shifting and tax competition. The EU, advocating multilateral tax reform, proposed harmonizing rules to prevent disparities. The Parliament will discuss adopting an EU directive implementing the OECD agreement, setting a 15% minimum effective tax rate for multinational enterprises exceeding €750 million annual turnover.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the global minimum tax agreement as a historic step to combat tax avoidance, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fair competition and market stability.  
EPP applauds the directive's harmonization of tax rules across member states, effectively advancing their priority of preventing regulatory arbitrage while maintaining EU competitiveness.  
EPP proposes monitoring third-country implementation timelines to ensure global parity, emphasizing the need for equivalent action by non-EU partners to protect European businesses.  
EPP endorses the 15% rate as a balanced interim measure but suggests future reviews consider incremental increases to 20% after 2027 to match evolving global standards.  
EPP emphasizes the urgency of Council adoption without dilution, strongly opposing any delays that could undermine the EU’s leadership in global tax governance reform.

SD strongly upholds the enhanced reporting requirements in Articles 4 and 10, aligning perfectly with their commitment to tax transparency and closing loopholes for multinational corporations.  
SD applauds the directive’s safeguards against regulatory arbitrage, effectively advancing their priority of equitable competition and fair redistribution across EU member states.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of implementing the global minimum tax to redirect €60 billion annually toward green transitions and social recovery, as stressed in the issue’s alignment with fiscal justice.  
SD proposes reinforcing enforcement mechanisms by requiring quarterly compliance updates to member states, ensuring swift adoption despite current political blockades.  
SD fully sanctions the amendments protecting SMEs from unfair multinational dominance, reflecting their manifesto pledge to balance corporate power with worker and small business interests.

RENEW strongly agrees the enhanced transparency framework in Articles 13 and 27, which align perfectly with RENEW’s commitment to combating tax avoidance through auditable public disclosure mechanisms.  

RENEW approves the safeguards against regulatory arbitrage in Recitals 19-20, effectively advancing the priority of maintaining a level playing field across the internal market.  

RENEW proposes amending Article 42 to include quarterly interim reporting benchmarks, ensuring real-time compliance without altering the issue’s core enforcement architecture.  

RENEW applauds the revised definitions of taxable activities under Article 4, which match their manifesto pledge to eliminate loopholes in digital economy taxation.  

RENEW urges swift adoption of the amended directive’s Article 53 provisions, reinforcing their longstanding advocacy for multinational accountability through harmonized EU rules.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally sanctions the issue as a critical first step toward dismantling tax havens, perfectly aligning with their commitment to transnational fiscal justice and social equity.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the strengthened transparency requirements and enforcement mechanisms in Articles 10 and 27, which effectively advance their manifesto priority of combating corporate tax avoidance.  
GREEN_EFA urges immediate activation of Treaty-based solutions under Article 116 TFEU to bypass unanimity barriers, aligning with their systemic campaign to eliminate nationalist vetoes in tax policy.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s urgency in adopting the directive to preserve global implementation, endorsing the rapporteur’s strategy to prevent collapse of the OECD/G20 agreement.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the necessity of uniform application across all member states to eliminate internal market distortions, directly advancing their vision of tax fairness as a social justice imperative.

ECR rejects the directive's current framework for granting excessive delegated powers to the Commission, fully condemning with their principle that taxation should remain a member state competence.  
ECR opposes the accelerated adoption timeline as it fails to address the unresolved Pillar I OECD negotiations, creating an imbalanced global playing field.  
The proposal overlooks critical economic impacts by lacking a comprehensive assessment of how increased corporate tax burdens will affect consumers and workers.  
ECR fundamentally disputes the directive's approach to regulatory arbitrage, arguing it will lead to new bureaucratic layers rather than genuine tax fairness.  
The issue's implementation risks contradicting ECR's stance on tax competition by imposing harmonized rules that disregard national sovereignty in fiscal policy.

ID supports the directive's framework for multinational tax equity but proposes amending Article 15 to increase the minimum rate beyond 15%, aligning it with domestic corporate tax levels to prevent competitive imbalances.  
ID advises revising Article 53 to implement parallel tax relief measures for SMEs, ensuring equitable treatment compared to multinational entities under the harmonized rules.  
ID emphasizes the importance of Recital 24’s safeguards against regulatory arbitrage, urging stricter penalties in Article 42 for profit-shifting practices by large corporations.  
ID highlights concerns that the 15% threshold risks perpetuating lower effective rates for multinationals compared to resident businesses, advocating for upward adjustment to ensure parity.  
ID calls for transparency mechanisms in Article 29 to prioritize multinational compliance audits while exempting SMEs from redundant reporting obligations.

GUE_NGL supports the directive's harmonization efforts but advises revising Article 4 to set a 25% minimum rate, tripling potential state revenues while preventing it from becoming a de facto ceiling.  
GUE_NGL welcomes transparency measures in Articles 27-29 but proposes expanding Article 15 to cover real estate investment funds and tax-sheltered vehicles enabling housing speculation.  
GUE_NGL slightly approves the OECD framework while urging amendments to Article 10 to close loopholes allowing digital giants to maintain sub-5% effective tax rates through jurisdictional arbitrage.  
GUE_NGL advises lowering the €750 million revenue threshold in Article 53 to include 85-90% of multinationals currently excluded, preventing selective application favoring largest corporations.  
GUE_NGL acknowledges anti-arbitrage provisions as progress but demands Article 42 revisions to mandate biannual rate reviews with binding developing economy participation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2021 proposal (COM(2021)0823) under Article 115 TFEU, approving the amended directive aimed at harmonizing tax rules across member states. The resolution introduced 43 amendments to the proposal, modifying provisions across multiple recitals (6, 7, 13-14, 16, 18-20, 23-24) and articles (4, 10, 13, 15, 19, 21, 27, 29, 31, 41-42, 47, 50, 52-53), including new paragraphs and subparagraphs to strengthen transparency, enforcement, and alignment with EU objectives. Key revisions included enhanced reporting requirements for tax authorities, clearer definitions of taxable activities, and safeguards against regulatory arbitrage. The Parliament urged the Commission to incorporate these amendments into the final proposal and called on the Council to consult Parliament again if deviating from the approved text or making substantial changes. It emphasized the need for consistent application of rules to prevent distortions in the internal market and instructed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments for further action.

title: Financial activities of the European Investment Bank - annual report 2020: REPORT on the financial activities of the European Investment Bank – annual report 2020 | A9-0200/2021 | European Parliament
background: In 2020, the European Investment Bank addressed COVID-19 economic impacts through emergency financing while advancing climate objectives under the Paris Agreement and European Green Deal. As the EU’s primary public lender, its governance, transparency practices, and alignment with EU policy priorities faced scrutiny. The Parliament will discuss the EIB’s 2020 financial activities and institutional role in EU strategic goals.

stances.stance:
EPP completely advocates the EIB’s prioritization of SME support through €30.56 billion in financing, perfectly aligning with EPP’s commitment to safeguarding Europe’s economic backbone and 425,000 businesses during crises.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on transitional technologies like gas, ensuring sustainable transformation while protecting industrial competitiveness and jobs, as emphasized in the Climate Bank Roadmap.  
EPP completely advocates strengthening technical assistance for InvestEU national compartments, reflecting the EPP’s focus on practical implementation of recovery tools at local levels.  
EPP unequivocally supports the EIB’s anti-fraud and transparency measures, which advance EPP’s longstanding priority of accountable EU financial governance.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s climate investment targets, recognizing the EIB’s €19 billion contribution to renewable energy in member states like Ireland as transformative for green transition goals.

SD firmly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on expanding the EIB’s capital base to sustain its AAA rating, proposing enhanced democratic accountability through direct EU budget contributions to the EIB’s capital structure to strengthen parliamentary oversight.  
SD perfectly aligns with calls to prioritize SME financing and accelerate EGF disbursements, urging immediate operational adjustments to meet the 40% allocation target for SMEs while maintaining alignment with pandemic recovery timelines.  
SD supports the Climate Bank Roadmap’s Paris Agreement alignment as a model for global leadership, advocating stricter monitoring of airport expansion phase-outs and fossil fuel divestment to ensure 2021-2025 targets are met.  
SD emphasizes the need to address geographical lending imbalances through revised allocation criteria, ensuring peripheral and insular regions receive equitable climate and transport investments under the Just Transition Mechanism.  
SD proposes strengthening the EIB’s anti-fraud framework and HR governance by implementing transparent leadership recruitment processes and reducing ethics committee waivers to align with parliamentary transparency demands.

GREEN_EFA entirely agrees the issue’s climate ambition, perfectly aligning with their demand for 100% renewable energy investments and the immediate end to fossil fuel financing.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening transparency by publishing full ethics committee issues publicly, not restricting access to Luxembourg reading rooms, to enhance accountability.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly supports strict Paris Agreement alignment, urging accelerated timelines to replace all transitional fossil infrastructure with science-based decarbonization plans by 2023.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the call for gender-balanced leadership, emphasizing the need to rectify underrepresentation in EIB’s senior roles through binding quotas.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the push to prioritize grants over loans in external lending, aligning with their stance on climate justice and avoiding debt traps in vulnerable nations.

ECR absolutely againsts the issue's climate investment targets as they fail to mandate independent value-for-money assessments, risking inefficient allocation of resources inconsistent with fiscal responsibility principles.  
ECR rejects the proposed expansion of EIB climate financing without concrete mechanisms to ensure long-term economic growth, arguing this mirrors past failed EU competitiveness strategies that prioritized labeling over productivity.  
ECR highlights the issue's contradiction with innovation-driven recovery by neglecting measurable outcomes for SME support programs, which ECR considers vital for sustainable post-pandemic growth.  
ECR criticizes the absence of strict cost-benefit analysis requirements in climate projects, asserting this undermines accountability and could replicate the "obsolete 2010 competitiveness agenda" referenced in debate arguments.  
ECR disputes the issue's approach to pandemic recovery funding as overly focused on green labeling rather than productive investments, directly conflicting with ECR's demand for growth-oriented "innovative investment culture."

ID rejects the issue's endorsement of EIB's capital increase as fully challengeing with ID's principle that the EIB is a member-state institution requiring national fiscal sovereignty over investment decisions.  
ID opposes continued EIB lending to Turkey as inconsistent with EU values, demanding amendments to suspend all financing to governments undermining democratic freedoms per Article 5.  
ID slightly approves climate financing targets but requests revising the 2025 decarbonization quota to prioritize digital infrastructure investments critical for economic recovery.  
ID demands strict amendments to grant the European Court of Auditors full investigative powers over EIB operations, citing the issue's failure to address accountability gaps in Section 9.3.  
ID rejects the issue's external lending priorities, urging deletion of non-EU project allocations that lack binding social/environmental safeguards as outlined in Paragraph 12.

GUE_NGL strongly upholds the issue's climate financing targets and fossil fuel divestment timeline, which align perfectly with their longstanding commitment to ecological transition and climate justice.  
GUE_NGL applauds the prioritization of SME support through the European Guarantee Fund, urging explicit quotas to ensure micro-enterprises in peripheral regions receive 40% of allocated funds.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally upholds demands for gender parity in leadership roles, emphasizing the need for binding recruitment targets and third-party oversight of harassment investigations.  
GUE_NGL strongly approves the emphasis on social infrastructure investments, recognizing this as a critical step toward materializing the European Pillar of Social Rights in healthcare and affordable housing.  
GUE_NGL welcomes transparency improvements while demanding real-time public disclosure of all EIB project risk assessments to strengthen democratic accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of the European Investment Bank (EIB) in addressing the COVID-19 crisis, climate action, and sustainable development, emphasizing its mobilization of EUR 40 billion in emergency financing and EUR 25 billion through the European Guarantee Fund (EGF) to support SMEs, mid-caps, and healthcare. It highlighted the EIB’s approval of EUR 23.5 billion for 84 EU COVID-19 operations by September 2020, with 88% targeting SMEs and health sectors, and EUR 5.2 billion for non-EU countries. The resolution stressed the need for continued EGF operations beyond 2021 due to prolonged pandemic impacts. Parliament welcomed the EIB’s Climate Bank Roadmap 2021-2025, aiming to increase climate-related financing to 50% by 2025, align with the Paris Agreement by 2023, and end fossil fuel investments by 2021, while phasing out airport expansion support by 2022. It called for a capital increase to sustain the EIB’s AAA rating and enhance investments in green and digital transitions, noting the EUR 350 billion annual climate investment gap. The resolution urged stronger support for SMEs (EUR 30.56 billion in 2020, aiding 425,000 firms), innovation (EUR 14.43 billion in 2020), and social infrastructure, including health, education, and housing. It emphasized addressing regional disparities, enhancing transparency, and avoiding conflicts of interest, advocating for stricter anti-fraud measures, gender equality (51.4% female workforce but underrepresentation in leadership), and human rights due diligence. The EIB’s external lending (EUR 10.23 billion in 2020, including EUR 2.3 billion for least developed countries) was urged to align with EU standards, prioritize SDGs, and avoid debt burdens through grants over loans. Parliament also called for improved governance, accountability, and cooperation with EU bodies, stressing the need for harmonized project assessments using the EU taxonomy and DNSH criteria.

title: A comprehensive Union policy on preventing money laundering and terrorist financing – Commission's Action plan and other recent developments: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on a comprehensive Union policy on preventing money laundering and terrorist financing – the Commission’s Action Plan and other recent developments | B9-0207/2020 | European Parliament
background: The European Commission’s May 2020 Action Plan and 2019 Anti-Money Laundering Package addressed fragmented EU AML/CTF rules, high-risk third countries, and COVID-19-related financial crimes, amid major scandals (Danske Bank, Wirecard) and low asset recovery rates. The Parliament will discuss a comprehensive EU policy to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally approves the issue's mandate for immediate infringement procedures against non-compliant Member States, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to rigorous enforcement exemplified by the Daphne Caruana Galizia case.  
EPP fundamentally approves the creation of a centralized EU AML/CTF supervisor with direct oversight powers, which resolves fragmentation issues raised in national implementation failures like Wirecard and Danske Bank.  
EPP fundamentally approves harmonizing AML/CTF rules through a binding regulation, eliminating divergent national transpositions that enable criminal networks to exploit regulatory loopholes.  
EPP fundamentally approves empowering Europol and the EPPO to dismantle cross-border financial crime networks, reflecting EPP's 2023 priorities for integrated judicial and law enforcement frameworks.  
EPP fundamentally approves phasing out citizenship-by-investment schemes, a critical measure to sever criminal access to EU financial systems as highlighted in Malta’s Nexia BT scandals.

SD firmly sanctions the establishment of a unified EU AML/CTF rulebook via binding regulations, perfectly aligning with S&D's demand to replace fragmented directives with harmonized standards for beneficial ownership transparency and cross-border enforcement.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's urgency in creating a centralized EU supervisory authority, reflecting S&D's repeated calls for direct oversight of high-risk financial entities to prevent scandals like Danske Bank's €200 billion laundering case.  
SD fully supports mandatory interconnection of national financial intelligence units and real-time data sharing, mirroring S&D's emphasis on closing coordination gaps that allowed €96 billion in opaque Russian investments through Dutch channels.  
SD strongly advocates for eliminating citizenship-by-investment schemes and retroactive audits of golden visas, directly addressing S&D's concerns about Malta's handling of Daphne Caruana Galizia's assassination and related corruption revelations.  
SD firmly sanctions applying dissuasive EU-level sanctions for delayed directive implementation, perfectly consistent with S&D's condemnation of Member States failing to operationalize the 5AMLD while demanding Europol-led asset recovery mechanisms.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the Commission’s Action Plan to replace fragmented directives with a harmonized AML/CTF rulebook via regulation, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to closing enforcement gaps through EU-level legal certainty.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the creation of an EU AML/CTF supervisor and FIU as critical to overcoming national supervisory failures exposed in cases like Danske Bank, effectively advancing their priority of cross-border accountability.  
GREEN_EFA endorses asset recovery reforms to redirect confiscated criminal funds to victims and public services, mirroring their manifesto demands for justice in high-profile cases such as Daphne Caruana Galizia’s assassination.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing enforcement by urging the Commission to initiate infringement procedures not only for delayed transposition but also for systemic non-enforcement of older AML directives, ensuring real-world compliance.  
GREEN_EFA approves expanding AML/CTF rules to crypto-assets and high-risk jurisdictions, emphasizing this matches their advocacy to eliminate loopholes exploited in scandals like Wirecard’s €1.9 billion fraud.

ECR rejects the proposal's approach to NGOs, arguing it fails to mandate equal transparency for non-profits, creating loopholes for illicit financing.  
ECR opposes the creation of an EU-level AML supervisor, asserting that centralized oversight undermines national sovereignty in fiscal policy enforcement.  
ECR firmly conflicts with the issue's insufficient measures against aggressive tax havens within the EU, demanding stricter sanctions on member states with opaque banking systems.  
ECR highlights that Poland's proven VAT fraud recovery systems demonstrate effective national-level enforcement, rendering additional EU bureaucracy unnecessary.  
ECR criticizes the issue's global cooperation focus while overlooking the need for binding intra-EU fiscal compliance mechanisms.

ID rejects the issue's framework for systematically exempting NGOs from AML/CTF oversight, absolutely rejecting with ID's demand to regulate entities like the Open Society Foundation which operate with €20 billion in non-transparent funding.  

ID opposes the proposal's failure to ban anonymous trust/nominee structures that enable unverified financial transfers, directly contradicting ID's insistence on eliminating legal loopholes for terrorist financing channels.  

ID condemns the issue's refusal to impose transparency requirements on NGOs despite Moneyval and Europol warnings, overlooking critical risks where groups like ISIS exploited such entities for financing.  

ID rejects continued EU development funding to Pakistan (€2.4 billion 2014-2020) despite FATF monitoring, highlighting the issue's hypocrisy in sanctioning third countries while ignoring state-sponsored terrorism by EU allies.  

ID opposes the inadequate regulation of electronic currencies permitting untraceable transactions, a critical flaw given ID's evidence of terror networks exploiting these systems for "enrichissement sans cause."

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over significant gaps in EU anti-money laundering (AML) and counter-terrorist financing (CTF) frameworks, noting that €160 billion (1% of EU GDP) is linked to illicit financial activities annually, with 98.9% of criminal profits remaining unconfiscated. It endorsed the Commission’s May 2020 Action Plan, urging swift advancement on its six pillars, including a single AML/CTF rulebook via a regulation to harmonize rules on beneficial ownership transparency, customer due diligence, supervision standards, and cross-border cooperation. The resolution called for an EU-level AML/CTF supervisor with direct oversight powers over high-risk entities and an EU Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) to enhance cross-border coordination. It stressed the need to expand AML/CTF obligations to crypto-assets, non-financial sectors, and high-risk third countries, advocating stricter criteria for listing jurisdictions with strategic deficiencies and countermeasures against non-cooperative states. The Parliament criticized delayed transposition of the 4th and 5th AML Directives (4AMLD/5AMLD) by Member States, urging infringement procedures and improved enforcement, particularly in high-profile cases like Danske Bank, Wirecard (€1.9 billion missing), and the assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia. It emphasized strengthening asset recovery mechanisms, interconnecting national registries, and phasing out citizenship/residency-by-investment schemes. Additional measures included empowering Europol, the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO), and Eurojust, enhancing financial investigations, and addressing COVID-19-related AML/CTF risks. The resolution highlighted systemic weaknesses in supervision, data accuracy in beneficial ownership registers, and the need for harmonized sanctions, while urging transparency in third-country assessments and stricter oversight of tax crimes and predicate offenses.

title: Impact of national tax reforms on the EU economy: REPORT on the impact of national tax reforms on the EU economy | A9-0348/2021 | European Parliament
background: Ongoing EU tax policy frameworks under TFEU provisions, OECD/G20 tax reform initiatives, post-pandemic national fiscal adjustments, and divergent national approaches to digitalization and environmental transitions created disparities affecting cross-border competition and revenue stability. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing tax policies to address single market distortions and economic cohesion challenges.
resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about harmful tax practices, tax competition, and policy fragmentation undermining the EU single market, citing annual revenue losses from corporate tax avoidance ranging between €36-37 billion and €160-190 billion. It emphasized the disproportionate burden on SMEs, which face tax compliance costs up to 30% of taxes paid compared to 2% for multinational enterprises (MNEs), and highlighted risks of double taxation, legal uncertainty, and market distortions. The resolution welcomed the OECD/G20 two-pillar tax reform, including a global minimum 15% effective corporate tax rate, urging swift EU implementation by 2023. It advocated for harmonization measures such as the proposed Business in Europe Framework for Income Taxation (BEFIT) to simplify cross-border operations for SMEs and reduce compliance costs, while stressing the need to phase out national digital taxes in favor of an international solution. The Parliament called for addressing debt-equity bias by limiting interest deductions to 20-30% of EBITDA, harmonizing VAT, and reforming tax incentives for R&D to prioritize expenditure-based over profit-based schemes. It noted stark disparities in tax-to-GDP ratios (22.1% in Ireland vs. 46.1% in Denmark) and corporate tax rate declines (from 46.52% in 1980 to 25.85% in 2020), urging Member States to align tax policies with EU objectives, enhance administrative cooperation, and utilize the EU Tax Scoreboard to monitor distortions. The resolution also emphasized post-COVID recovery reforms, digitalization of tax systems, and combating aggressive tax planning through improved enforcement of the Directive on Administrative Cooperation and country-specific recommendations.

title: Implementation of EU requirements for exchange of tax information: REPORT on the implementation of the EU requirements for exchange of tax information: progress, lessons learnt and obstacles to overcome | A9-0193/2021 | European Parliament
background: The EU Directive on Administrative Cooperation in taxation (DAC), established in 2011 and amended through DAC4 (2017), mandated cross-border tax information exchange. Member States largely denied the European Parliament access to implementation documents in 2020, citing confidentiality under inter-institutional agreements, limiting oversight capacity. The Parliament will discuss challenges in enforcing EU tax transparency rules and institutional cooperation barriers.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly supports the issue's emphasis on rigorous enforcement of tax information exchange rules, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to combatting cross-border tax evasion through enhanced administrative cooperation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call to expand DAC scope to cover capital gains and non-financial assets, proposing strengthening anti-money laundering frameworks to ensure data quality as a critical enhancement opportunity.  
EPP firmly supports the demand for annual summaries of exchanged data, which advances EPP's priority of transparent fiscal governance while urging accelerated adoption of compliance guidelines for Member States.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s critique of systemic implementation gaps, advocating reinforced inter-institutional cooperation to eliminate reporting loopholes in line with EPP’s 2023 competitiveness agenda.  
EPP firmly supports leveraging the Fiscalis 2020 program to reduce bureaucratic burdens, aligning with EPP’s principle of efficient tax administrations that protect taxpayer rights while combating fraud.

SD fully advocates the issue’s emphasis on rigorous enforcement of DAC frameworks, perfectly aligning with SD’s longstanding commitment to combat tax evasion through robust inter-institutional cooperation and data transparency.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call to expand DAC’s scope to cover capital gains and non-financial assets, as highlighted by recent scandals involving art and yachts, which undermine fair taxation and public trust.  
SD fully advocates the issue’s criticism of member states’ obstruction of data access, echoing SD’s priority to strengthen parliamentary oversight under Article 14 TFEU and eliminate undemocratic confidentiality barriers.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for annual summaries of exchanged data and cost-benefit frameworks, addressing systemic gaps in monitoring and compliance that enable corporate tax avoidance.  
SD fully advocates the urgency of harmonizing AML rules across the EU, as weak national frameworks and FATF deficiencies directly contradict SD’s vision of a transparent, equitable fiscal union.

ECR rejects the issue's expanded DAC scope as totally condemning with national tax sovereignty protections under EU treaties, a core ECR principle.  
ECR opposes mandatory reporting extensions for non-financial assets, citing disproportionate bureaucratic burdens on businesses inconsistent with ECR's competitiveness agenda.  
ECR totally condemns with proposals to weaken tax competition, which the issue frames negatively despite ECR's evidence of its role in driving fiscal efficiency.  
ECR challenges DAC8 harmonization efforts as Treaty overreach, noting the issue fails to respect unanimous voting requirements for direct taxation matters.  
ECR condemns infringement procedures against member states' tax regimes as incompatible with subsidiarity, highlighting Poland's successful defense of national fiscal measures.

ID entirely rejects the EU’s centralized tax surveillance mechanisms, which violate subsidiarity by overriding national fiscal sovereignty as enshrined in EU treaties.  
ID rejects the expansion of DAC scope to non-financial assets as bureaucratic overreach, emphasizing tax policy must remain exclusively with member states rather than supranational bodies.  
The issue fails to address ID’s core critique of exempting NGOs and climate-focused trusts from AML rules despite evidence of their misuse for tax evasion and illicit financing.  
ID condemns the systemic inequity in targeting citizens’ compliance while allowing digital giants like Big Tech to avoid €50B+ in taxes through legal loopholes unchallenged by the DAC framework.  
Proposals for EU-wide asset registers contradict ID’s defense of privacy rights, creating disproportionate risks of data leaks without tackling root causes like offshore corporate structures.

GUE_NGL absolutely advocates the issue’s condemnation of institutional secrecy blocking parliamentary oversight, perfectly aligning with their demand for absolute transparency in combating elite tax evasion.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with expanding DAC to cover capital gains and non-financial assets like real estate, critical to dismantling loopholes exploited by wealthy tax avoiders.  
GUE_NGL absolutely advocates rigorous enforcement of anti-money laundering rules, emphasizing the urgency to address systemic failures highlighted by FATF’s damning assessments.  
GUE_NGL strongly upholds annual public summaries of tax data exchanges, ensuring democratic accountability and mirroring their manifesto pledge to eradicate fiscal secrecy.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with exposing tax rulings through enhanced transparency, vital to preventing scandals like LuxLetters and curtailing corporate-state collusion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over insufficient access to documents and data necessary to assess the implementation of the Directive on Administrative Cooperation (DAC) in taxation, hindering its oversight role under Article 14 TFEU and the 2016 Inter-Institutional Agreement. Despite requests, most Member States (except Sweden and Finland) blocked access via the Commission, citing confidentiality under a 2010 agreement, leaving the Parliament reliant on limited 2015-2017 data from an Economisti Associati study and patchy public sources. The DAC framework, expanded through DAC1-4, mandates automatic exchange of tax-related information on income categories (employment, pensions, financial accounts, tax rulings, and Country-by-Country Reports for multinationals with €750M+ revenue), but gaps persist in covering capital gains, non-financial assets (e.g., art, yachts), and loopholes in financial reporting. The Parliament criticized poor data quality, inconsistent monitoring, and weak compliance checks by Member States, with only a few conducting audits or quality assessments. It urged the Commission to issue guidelines, establish a cost-benefit framework, and publish annual summaries of exchanged data. Weak anti-money laundering (AML) rules in many Member States and FATF’s low effectiveness ratings further undermine DAC’s impact. Internationally, OECD reviews found 10 EU states non-compliant with the Common Reporting Standard and 18 with material deficiencies in information exchange, highlighting systemic risks. The resolution stressed the need for rigorous enforcement of existing rules, expanded DAC scope, and improved inter-institutional cooperation to combat tax evasion, fraud, and avoidance effectively.

title: Implementation of the Sixth VAT Directive: REPORT on the implementation of the Sixth VAT Directive: what is the missing part to reduce the EU VAT gap? | A9-0355/2021 | European Parliament
background: Persistent EU VAT revenue losses, exacerbated by COVID-19, and a transitional system since 1993 under Directive 2006/112/EC, alongside proposals for a definitive fraud-proof framework, have highlighted divergent national VAT gaps and compliance complexities. The Parliament will discuss Sixth VAT Directive implementation challenges and strategies to reduce revenue shortfalls.
resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the implementation and challenges of the EU VAT system, particularly under Directive 2006/112/EC (recast from the 6th VAT Directive), highlighting a significant VAT gap—estimated at €140 billion (11% of expected revenue) in 2020, rising to €164 billion (13.7%) due to COVID-19 impacts. The resolution emphasized the need to transition from the transitional VAT system, prone to fraud like carousel schemes, to a definitive regime based on the destination principle, taxing cross-border B2B transactions in the customer’s country. It noted disparities in VAT gaps across Member States, ranging from 1% in Sweden and Croatia to 33% in Romania, and stressed the economic burden on SMEs, with compliance costs accounting for 1-4% of turnover. The Parliament criticized fragmented VAT rates and exemptions (over 250 in the EU) for distorting the internal market, increasing compliance costs, and undermining social and environmental goals, as reduced VAT rates often fail to benefit consumers effectively, eroding tax bases by up to 22% of domestic revenue. It urged rationalizing reduced rates, harmonizing tax systems, and leveraging digitization to combat fraud and simplify processes, while advocating for the adoption of the 2018 proposal to establish a single VAT area. The resolution also linked post-pandemic recovery via the Recovery and Resilience Facility to fairer, greener taxation, stressing that closing VAT gaps and improving efficiency are critical for debt repayment and economic resilience.

title: Digital taxation: OECD negotiations, tax residency of digital companies and a possible European Digital Tax: REPORT on digital taxation: OECD negotiations, tax residency of digital companies and a possible European Digital Tax | A9-0103/2021 | European Parliament
background: Outdated international tax rules designed for physical economies struggled to address digitalized business models, with OECD-led BEPS reforms ongoing since 2015. Accelerated digitalization during COVID-19 heightened tax base erosion concerns, while divergent EU member states' unilateral digital taxes risked market fragmentation. The Parliament will discuss modernizing corporate tax frameworks for digital enterprises and potential EU-level solutions.

stances.stance:
SD absolutely promotes the issue’s swift adoption of the OECD two-pillar solution, perfectly aligning with S&D’s longstanding commitment to equitable taxation and combating profit shifting by digital multinationals.  
SD perfectly aligns with the urgency to establish a global minimum corporate tax rate, emphasizing that this measure must comprehensively include all digital giants to prevent regulatory loopholes and advance fair market competition.  
SD fully supports the European Digital Tax as a critical fallback mechanism, effectively advancing S&D’s priority to ensure digital enterprises contribute their fair share to public finances and COVID-19 recovery.  
SD underscores the necessity of harmonized EU coordination to enforce taxing rights in market jurisdictions, reflecting S&D’s principle of taxing value creation where user participation occurs.  
SD emphasizes safeguarding SMEs from disproportionate burdens, aligning perfectly with the issue’s focus on equitable contributions from large digital corporations without disadvantaging smaller businesses.

ECR firmly againsts the issue's approach to EU tax harmonization as violating member states' sovereign rights to set fiscal policies, directly conflicting with ECR's core principle of national subsidiarity in taxation matters.  
ECR rejects the proposed EU-wide digital services tax as an unacceptable encroachment on member states' exclusive competency to determine corporate tax regimes, mirroring Możdżanowska's warning against "treating states like children" needing EU supervision.  
The issue's endorsement of a digital levy as an EU own resource totally challenges with ECR's stance against expanding supranational financing mechanisms, which undermines national budgetary autonomy.  
ECR condemns the issue's implicit acceptance of majority voting on tax issues as disregarding Możdżanowska's demand to "reject majority dictates" and preserve unanimous decision-making for fiscal sovereignty.  
The proposal's reliance on OECD-led multilateralism overlooks ECR's insistence that any digital tax framework must strictly emerge from voluntary agreements between sovereign states without EU institutional coercion.

GUE_NGL firmly advocates the issue's urgency in taxing digital giants as a critical step toward corporate tax justice, perfectly aligning with their manifesto demands to end privileges for multinationals.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening provisions to close profit-shifting loopholes by mandating binding country-by-country reporting rules, ensuring transparency that prevents tropical tax havens from undermining reforms.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the call for a global minimum corporate tax but urges exceeding the OECD’s proposed rate to decisively dismantle tax competition models favoring capital over public welfare.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes that taxing tech giants must directly fund collective services and COVID recovery, rejecting half-measures that allow continued austerity for workers while corporations evade responsibilities.  
The issue effectively advances GUE_NGL’s priority of shifting tax burdens from SMEs to Big Tech, though implementation must bar carve-outs letting firms like Amazon exploit jurisdictional arbitrage.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over outdated international tax rules ill-suited for a digitalized economy, emphasizing the need for reforms to address profit shifting, tax avoidance, and under-taxation of digital businesses. It highlighted that digital companies face an average effective tax rate of 9.5% compared to 23.2% for traditional businesses, exacerbating inequalities and market distortions, particularly disadvantaging SMEs. The resolution urged swift adoption of the OECD/G20 Inclusive Framework’s two-pillar solution: Pillar One to reallocate taxing rights to market jurisdictions based on user participation and value creation, and Pillar Two to establish a global minimum corporate tax rate (ideally set to deter profit shifting). It stressed the urgency of a multilateral agreement by mid-2021 to prevent fragmented national measures, such as uncoordinated digital services taxes (DSTs), which risk trade disputes and single market fragmentation. The Parliament called for an EU fallback position, including a temporary EU-wide DST by end-2021 if international talks fail, and endorsed a digital levy as a new EU own resource to generate €15-29.25 billion annually from 2023, funding COVID-19 recovery and EU programs. It emphasized harmonized implementation of OECD outcomes, simplification of tax rules to avoid complexity, and stronger EU coordination to ensure fair taxation of multinationals, particularly in market jurisdictions where value is created. The resolution also urged revisiting proposals like the CCCTB and significant digital presence, while safeguarding SMEs from undue burdens and ensuring digital tax revenues contribute equitably to public finances.

title: Reforming the EU policy on harmful tax practices (including the reform of the Code of Conduct Group): REPORT on reforming the EU policy on harmful tax practices (including the reform of the Code of Conduct Group) | A9-0245/2021 | European Parliament
background: The EU has addressed harmful tax practices since 1997 through the Code of Conduct Group, OECD BEPS initiatives, and an evolving list of non-cooperative jurisdictions. Persistent tax scandals, evolving digitalization, and pandemic-induced fiscal strains underscored systemic gaps. The Parliament will discuss reforming EU tax policy frameworks, including modernizing the Code of Conduct Group.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions modernizing the Code of Conduct Group to enforce binding economic substance criteria and OECD-aligned minimum taxation, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to fair corporate tax competition.  
EPP approves expanding anti-tax avoidance measures through public country-by-country reporting and anti-shell company rules, effectively advancing transparency priorities outlined in EPP's 2023 fiscal integrity agenda.  
EPP endorses leveraging Article 116 TFEU to create binding EU tools against harmful tax competition, reinforcing the Single Market's stability while respecting national sovereignty on rate-setting.  
EPP proposes maintaining the Code of Conduct's corporate tax focus rather than extending it to personal income schemes, ensuring proportionality while fully backing strengthened scrutiny of digital nomad arrangements.  
EPP applauds stricter EU listing of non-cooperative jurisdictions with concrete sanctions, urging accelerated implementation to close loopholes exposed by the Pandora Papers revelations.

SD completely sanctions the issue's call to reform the Code of Conduct Group by mandating public transparency in tax governance deliberations, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to democratic accountability in fiscal policy.  

SD perfectly aligns with the proposal to enforce a global minimum effective corporate tax rate of at least 15%, as highlighted in the OECD/G20 Pillar II framework, which directly addresses the systemic profit shifting condemned in the Pandora Papers revelations.  

SD completely sanctions expanding the EU tax haven listing criteria to include jurisdictions facilitating aggressive personal income tax avoidance, thereby closing loopholes exposed by digital nomad schemes and elite tax competition.  

SD perfectly supports integrating binding substance requirements and parliamentary oversight into the FATAL framework, ensuring multinational entities cannot exploit legal arbitrage between member states' regimes.  

SD completely sanctions implementing immediate sanctions against non-cooperative jurisdictions and entities identified in the Pandora Papers, operationalizing the European Semester's monitoring role to prevent revenue loss during pandemic recovery.

RENEW strongly upholds the issue’s alignment with OECD Pillar II’s 15% global minimum tax, a cornerstone of RENEW’s agenda to combat profit shifting and ensure multinationals pay their fair share.  
RENEW approves expanding the Code of Conduct’s scope to personal income tax schemes and digital nomads, proposing enhanced clarity in defining “economic substance” to prevent loopholes.  
RENEW applauds transparency measures such as public reporting and anti-shell company rules, which mirror their 2023 manifesto priorities for corporate accountability.  
RENEW endorses leveraging Article 116 TFEU to create binding EU tools against harmful tax competition, a critical step toward harmonizing fair taxation across member states.  
RENEW suggests accelerating the FATAL framework’s implementation timeline to ensure swift replacement of the outdated CoC, while maintaining robust parliamentary oversight.

GREEN_EFA strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on eradicating intra-EU tax havens and enforcing public transparency, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fiscal justice and systemic accountability.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the integration of climate justice with tax reforms, as this effectively advances their manifesto priority to combat environmental predation through equitable fiscal frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA proposes expanding the criteria for non-cooperative jurisdiction listings to explicitly include entities exposed in the Pandora Papers, enhancing alignment with anti-money laundering efforts.  
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses binding Article 116 TFEU measures to counter tax competition, noting this mirrors their longstanding demand for EU-level enforcement against corporate tax evasion.  
GREEN_EFA recommends strengthening parliamentary oversight in the FATAL framework by mandating civil society participation in audits, ensuring democratic scrutiny without opposing the core mechanism.

ECR rejects the issue's push for binding EU tax harmonization as fundamentally doubting with their principle of preserving national sovereignty in direct taxation.  
ECR opposes replacing consensus-based decision-making in the Code of Conduct Group with majority voting, which would override individual member states' fiscal policy autonomy.  
ECR condemns the issue's failure to address internal EU tax competition between member states as the primary cause of CIT revenue losses, rather than external tax havens.  
ECR fundamentally disputes the premise that fair tax competition must be suppressed, arguing the proposal overlooks healthy fiscal sovereignty's role in driving economic growth.  
ECR challenges the issue's alignment with OECD Pillar II minimum taxes as incompatible with their stance against supranational imposition of tax rates.

ID partially promotes the expansion of tax practice oversight to personal income schemes but demands explicit carve-outs for national family incentive policies like Hungary’s child tax exemptions.  

ID objects to binding EU tools under Article 116 TFEU, arguing this entirely condemns with ID’s principle that tax sovereignty must remain exclusively with member states.  

ID requests revising the FATAL framework’s parliamentary oversight provisions to exclude supranational voting rights, limiting oversight to technical audits by member-state-nominated experts.  

ID criticizes the issue’s anti-shell company measures as overlooking critical aspects of SME operational flexibility, proposing amended thresholds to exempt businesses with under €5 million turnover.  

ID warns that the 15% global minimum tax alignment fails to address disproportionate burdens on manufacturing sectors, urging a carve-out for strategic industries in Article 7(b).

GUE_NGL totally advocates the issue's binding criteria for economic substance requirements, perfectly aligning with their anti-tax haven agenda to halt corporate profit shifting.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the demand to expand the Code of Conduct Group’s scope, viewing the FATAL framework as essential to dismantle systemic tax competition between Member States.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes that public country-by-country reporting provisions advance their decades-long fight against fiscal secrecy and shell company abuse.  
GUE_NGL condemns right-wing obstruction of CoC reforms as reinforcing the urgency to implement Article 116 TFEU against predatory tax regimes like the Netherlands'.  
GUE_NGL asserts the issue’s global minimum tax alignment directly counters the "Pandora Papers"-exposed loopholes exploited by corporate elites and complicit governments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over harmful tax practices (HTP) and tax avoidance, citing an annual loss of €36-37 billion in EU corporate tax revenue due to avoidance, with global estimates ranging from €84-202 billion (OECD) to €160-190 billion (Parliament). It highlighted the EU’s reliance on the Code of Conduct on Business Taxation (CoC), which since 1997 has reviewed 480 tax regimes, deeming 130 harmful, but criticized its outdated focus on preferential regimes and failure to address aggressive general regimes or intra-EU profit shifting. The resolution urged reforms to the CoC, including binding criteria for economic substance, alignment with the OECD/G20 Pillar II global minimum effective tax rate of at least 15%, and expanded scope to cover personal income tax schemes and digital nomads. It called for stricter EU listing of non-cooperative jurisdictions (currently 12), closing loopholes that allow tax havens to evade scrutiny, and emphasized transparency through public reporting and anti-shell company measures. The Parliament supported implementing OECD BEPS measures, revising the Interest and Royalties Directive, and advancing the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB). It stressed the need for binding EU tools under Article 116 TFEU to combat tax competition distortions, alongside fair tax incentives and monitoring via the European Semester. The resolution also advocated for a reformed "Framework on Aggressive Tax Arrangements and Low Rates" (FATAL) to replace the CoC, integrating substance requirements, anti-avoidance countermeasures, and parliamentary oversight, while urging Member States to align recovery policies with equitable taxation to mitigate pandemic-related revenue losses.

title: Requirements for payment service providers: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2006/112/EC as regards introducing certain requirements for payment service providers | A9-0048/2019 | European Parliament
background: Persistent cross-border VAT fraud in e-commerce, evidenced by a 2017 EU VAT gap of €137.5 billion, and challenges in tracking digital transactions prompted the European Commission’s 2018 proposal to strengthen tax compliance. The Parliament will discuss amending VAT rules to enhance payment service providers’ reporting requirements for combating fraud.

stances.stance:
EPP completely approves the enhanced PSP reporting obligations as critical to closing the €137.5 billion VAT gap, perfectly aligning with their commitment to combat cross-border fraud through systemic transparency.  
EPP strongly accepts the centralized electronic payment data system, emphasizing its necessity to eliminate administrative fragmentation and create a true digital single market.  
EPP applauds the mandatory intergovernmental data sharing provisions, recognizing their vital role in exposing complex fraud schemes involving cryptocurrencies and shell companies.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's harmonized PSP requirements, viewing them as essential tools to protect SMEs and ensure fair competition in cross-border e-commerce.  
EPP endorses the streamlined fraud prevention mechanisms as a strategic advancement in EU tax governance, directly supporting their manifesto priorities for fiscal integrity.

SD completely approves the issue’s systematic documentation requirements for PSPs, perfectly aligning with S&D’s commitment to combatting VAT fraud and ensuring fair taxation across all economic actors.  
SD perfectly supports the cross-border cooperation mechanisms, recognizing their critical role in reclaiming €137 billion annually for public services like healthcare and education.  
SD completely approves expanding fraud prevention to virtual currency platforms as a natural enhancement to the issue’s existing framework for transactional transparency.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for centralized EU-level data systems to prevent tax evasion, reinforcing S&D’s priority of equitable fiscal policies and corporate accountability.  
SD completely approves leveraging Eurofisc and interinstitutional collaboration, effectively advancing SD’s mandate to dismantle economic crime networks exploiting VAT loopholes.

GREEN_EFA completely approves the issue's robust PSP reporting mandates as a vital step toward eradicating €5bn annual digital VAT fraud, perfectly aligning with their tax justice agenda.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of equipping tax administrations with sufficient resources and cross-border coordination mechanisms to operationalize Articles 243b-243c effectively.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the directive’s environmental coherence through fraud reduction but proposes extending VAT reforms to aviation sector exemptions in future legislation to fully align with COP21 goals.   
GREEN_EFA affirms that the enhanced transactional transparency under Article 113 TFEU advances their manifesto pledge for corporate accountability in digital marketplaces.  
GREEN_EFA demands swift adoption of the amended directive to prevent revenue losses undermining Green Deal financing.

ECR strongly sanctions the issue’s mandate for systematic documentation by payment service providers, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fiscal integrity and combating VAT fraud.  
ECR approves the harmonized reporting mechanisms and CESOP establishment, advancing cross-border tax transparency and addressing e-commerce challenges central to ECR’s policy goals.  
ECR proposes amending the proposal to require the Commission to conduct objective, data-driven analyses of transactional data, ensuring evidence-based dissemination of best practices to reduce VAT gaps.  
ECR commends Poland’s success in reducing VAT fraud as a model for EU-wide alignment with results-oriented governance, reflecting ECR’s advocacy for practical solutions.  
ECR underscores the issue’s compatibility with robust data protection standards, ensuring compliance with EU regulations while safeguarding consumer rights.

ID entirely rejects the issue's expansion of surveillance measures on payment providers, viewing it as an undemocratic encroachment that deepens state overreach inconsistent with fiscal sovereignty principles.  
The proposal's tax transparency mechanisms contradict ID's stance against excessive EU taxation, failing to address systemic inefficiencies while imposing higher burdens on citizens already facing stagnant wages and rising debt.  
ID rejects the issue's alignment with centralized tax harmonization under Article 113 TFEU, arguing it undermines national autonomy and accelerates supranational control over member states' fiscal policies.  
By prioritizing enhanced reporting requirements in Articles 243b/c, the directive exemplifies EU overregulation that ID contends exacerbates bureaucratic costs without tackling fraud root causes.  
The issue's focus on PSP monitoring disregards ID's demand for reduced EU fiscal integration, instead advancing an agenda of tax maximization that citizens explicitly oppose through democratic channels.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0812) to amend Directive 2006/112/EC on VAT rules, approving the proposal with amendments to strengthen compliance measures for payment service providers (PSPs). The resolution emphasized the need for PSPs to systematically document transactional information to ensure tax transparency and combat fraud, aligning with Article 113 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It introduced specific modifications, including new recitals and revised articles, such as Article 243b and 243c, to clarify PSP obligations and enhance reporting mechanisms. The Parliament urged the Commission to revise its proposal accordingly under Article 293(2) and called on the Council to consult Parliament again if intending to substantially alter the text. Additionally, it stressed the importance of interinstitutional cooperation, instructing its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure alignment with EU tax policy objectives.

title: Review of the macroeconomic legislative framework: REPORT on the review of the macroeconomic legislative framework for a better impact on Europe’s real economy and improved transparency of decision-making and democratic accountability | A9-0212/2021 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated economic disparities and public debt within the EU, testing existing fiscal rules under the Stability and Growth Pact. Pre-crisis critiques highlighted framework complexity, insufficient investment for green/digital transitions, and uneven enforcement. The Parliament will discuss reforming macroeconomic governance to enhance real economy impact, transparency, and accountability.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely sanctions the expenditure-based fiscal framework proposal, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to transparent rules that enable anti-cyclical policies while ensuring debt sustainability through government-controlled variables.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on leveraging NextGenerationEU instruments, emphasizing their critical role in maintaining expansionary fiscal policies for post-COVID recovery without premature consolidation.  
EPP entirely sanctions integrating climate risk assessments into debt sustainability analyses, effectively advancing EPP's priority of aligning fiscal governance with European Green Deal objectives through measurable safeguards.  
EPP perfectly supports the call for enhanced role of independent fiscal institutions, recognizing this as essential for achieving the issue's goals of improved democratic accountability and compliance monitoring.  
EPP entirely sanctions the simplification of Stability and Growth Pact rules through growth-oriented expenditure controls, mirroring EPP's longstanding advocacy for operational frameworks that balance fiscal responsibility with strategic investment needs.

SD totally upholds the issue’s call to permanently abandon pro-cyclical austerity rules, perfectly aligning with S&D’s commitment to prioritizing green and social investments over rigid debt-reduction timelines.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand for country-specific debt sustainability analyses, ensuring fiscal flexibility to address COVID-era debt without stifling recovery through arbitrary 60% GDP targets.  
SD totally upholds integrating a "golden rule" exempting climate and social infrastructure spending from deficit calculations, advancing the European Green Deal’s transformational agenda.  
SD perfectly supports establishing permanent EU fiscal capacity through NextGenerationEU’s evolution, recognizing collective investment as essential to counter asymmetric shocks and structural divergences.  
SD totally upholds binding alignment of macroeconomic governance with social equity principles, ensuring the European Semester advances poverty reduction and labor rights alongside fiscal stability.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s demand to end rigid fiscal rules, aligning perfectly with their commitment to climate action and social justice through transformative economic governance.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on exempting green and social investments from austerity measures, advancing their manifesto priorities for just ecological transition.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 4 to explicitly exclude Paris Agreement-aligned expenditures from deficit calculations, ensuring irreversible protection for climate-critical projects.  
GREEN_EFA endorses integrating democratic accountability into debt management frameworks, particularly through parliamentary oversight of the European Stability Mechanism.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s alignment with leveraging NGEU funds for sustainable recovery, a cornerstone of their economic justice agenda.

ECR rejects the issue's neglect of fiscal consolidation planning, firmly rejecting with ECR's principle that sustainable growth requires disciplined debt reduction strategies.  
ECR opposes the reliance on expansive fiscal policies and NextGenerationEU funding, viewing this as contradictory to ECR's stance against intergenerational debt burdens and economic short-termism.  
The proposal's failure to mandate immediate consolidation roadmaps directly conflicts with ECR's demand for preemptive identification of inefficient public expenditures to safeguard future taxpayers.  
ECR condemns the issue's dismissal of pro-cyclical adjustment safeguards, inconsistent with ECR's warnings about repeating pre-pandemic debt accumulation patterns.  
The omission of concrete repayment mechanisms for EU-level debt instruments like SURE violates ECR's insistence on transparent liability management to prevent permanent fiscal union by stealth.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's maintenance of Maastricht Treaty debt rules as fundamentally incompatible with their demand for complete abolition of fiscal constraints blocking public investment in social and ecological infrastructure.  
GUE_NGL opposes the expenditure-based system's "safeguards" for green investments as insufficiently binding, failing to prevent renewed austerity cycles that disproportionately harm southern Member States as warned by Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης.  
GUE_NGL condemns the framework's alignment with European Semester policies that João Pimenta Lopes identifies as enforcing corporate dominance over sovereign development strategies in Portugal and beyond.  
GUE_NGL declares the issue's debt sustainability analyses irredeemably flawed for excluding mandatory climate justice metrics and wealth taxation mechanisms to fund €470bn annual green transitions.  
GUE_NGL dismisses procedural reforms to the Macroeconomic Imbalance Procedure as structurally incapable of addressing Martin Schirdewan's documented €450bn German investment gap in healthcare and digital inclusion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the EU’s economic governance framework, emphasizing its complexity, pro-cyclical biases, and failure to reduce divergences or protect public investment, while highlighting the need for reform amid COVID-19 recovery. It noted the activation of the Stability and Growth Pact’s general escape clause until 2023 to enable fiscal flexibility, allowing Member States to adopt expansive measures (with EU aggregate debt-to-GDP exceeding 100%) and avoid premature consolidation. The resolution stressed the necessity of targeted fiscal support to address scarring effects, inequalities, and investment gaps, citing annual funding needs of €470 billion for environmental objectives, €142 billion for social infrastructure, and €190 billion to stabilize public capital. It called for a revised governance framework prioritizing sustainable growth, debt sustainability through country-specific adjustment paths, and simplified rules such as an expenditure-based system with safeguards for green and social investments. The Parliament advocated maintaining expansionary fiscal policies to support recovery, leveraging NextGenerationEU (NGEU) and SURE instruments, while ensuring transparent debt management and repayment plans. It emphasized aligning fiscal policies with the European Green Deal and social rights, integrating climate risks into debt sustainability analyses, and improving the Macroeconomic Imbalance Procedure (MIP) to address structural divergences. The resolution also urged stronger democratic accountability, enhanced role for independent fiscal institutions, and better coordination between EU and national levels to ensure ownership and compliance with reforms.

title: Strengthening the international role of the euro: REPORT on strengthening the international role of the euro | A9-0043/2021 | European Parliament
background: The euro, the EU’s second-most-used global currency, faces underutilized potential despite the bloc’s economic size and trade influence. Geopolitical shifts, Brexit, pandemic recovery efforts, and ECB analyses on currency internationalization prompted evaluation. The Parliament will discuss measures to strengthen the euro’s international role amid evolving global economic dynamics.
resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to strengthen the international role of the euro to enhance the EU’s financial autonomy, reduce reliance on the US dollar, and bolster resilience against external economic shocks. It emphasized completing the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU), Banking Union, and Capital Markets Union (CMU) to deepen financial integration, increase the supply of euro-denominated safe assets, and address market fragmentation. The resolution highlighted the €750 billion Next Generation EU recovery plan as a historic opportunity to boost the euro’s global standing through joint debt issuance, including green and social bonds, with €100 billion already raised via the SURE instrument. It stressed the importance of promoting the euro in strategic sectors like energy, trade, and digital finance, noting that over half of global green bonds were denominated in euros in 2019. The Parliament called for advancing the digital euro to adapt to digital transformation, ensuring cybersecurity, and maintaining price stability. It urged reducing reliance on non-EU financial infrastructures post-Brexit, extending TARGET2 operating hours by 2022, and fostering euro-denominated clearing. The resolution also advocated for stronger EU representation in international institutions, aligning policies with climate goals under the Paris Agreement, and mitigating risks from extraterritorial sanctions by enhancing the euro’s use in trade invoicing. Challenges included addressing fragmented fiscal policies, ensuring sustainable debt management, and balancing the benefits of internationalization with potential risks like capital flow volatility. The ECB’s role in maintaining price stability and expanding swap lines to ensure global euro liquidity was underscored, alongside calls for harmonized regulations in crypto-assets and anti-money laundering frameworks.

title: State of implementation of anti-money laundering legislation: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the state of implementation of the Union’s anti-money laundering legislation | B9-0045/2019/REV1 | European Parliament
background: Persistent delays in transposing the 4th and 5th EU Anti-Money Laundering Directives, alongside divergent national enforcement and high-risk third-country listing challenges, prompted scrutiny of systemic gaps in combating financial crimes. The Parliament will discuss the implementation status of EU anti-money laundering legislation and cross-border supervisory coordination.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds replacing directives with EU-wide regulations to eliminate regulatory fragmentation, aligning perfectly with their commitment to a harmonized single market.  
EPP endorses establishing an EU-level supervisory authority with direct enforcement powers, effectively advancing their priority of robust cross-border financial oversight.  
EPP approves the call for binding beneficial ownership registers by the 5AMLD deadline, reflecting their manifesto pledge for corporate transparency.  
EPP proposes enhancing whistleblower protection mechanisms in Article 9 to complement investigative journalism efforts against financial crimes.  
EPP emphasizes urgent resource allocation to FIUs and the EBA, consistent with their stance on institutional capacity-building to combat illicit flows.

SD strongly upholds the issue's push for harmonized AML/CTF rules through directly applicable regulations, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to combat financial crime through EU-level integration.  
SD endorses the call for public beneficial ownership registers and cross-border FIU cooperation, effectively advancing SD's priority to dismantle opaque financial networks enabling tax evasion and corruption.  
SD proposes accelerating the establishment of a permanent EU anti-money laundering supervisory authority to address systemic supervisory gaps exposed by the Danske Bank case, while fully backing interim coordination mechanisms.  
SD strongly upholds the issue's criticism of "golden visa" schemes, urging enhanced due diligence requirements for residency-by-investment programs as a critical enhancement to existing AML safeguards.  
SD approves the demand for EBA governance reform to eliminate conflicts of interest in breach investigations, mirroring SD's longstanding advocacy for accountable EU financial oversight.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates establishing robust EU-level supervisory institutions to combat financial crime, aligning perfectly with their manifesto commitment to transnational accountability frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA approves mandatory beneficial ownership registers while proposing enhanced machine-readable data standards to enable civil society oversight as a critical enhancement opportunity.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally agrees systematic infringement procedures against non-compliant states, effectively advancing their priority of eliminating regulatory arbitrage in financial governance.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes urgent implementation of third-country risk lists with autonomous methodology, reflecting their longstanding demand to sever diplomatic influences from anti-corruption mechanisms.  
GREEN_EFA applauds linking AML enforcement resourcing to Europol’s €190 billion illicit flow estimates, strongly advocateing budget increases proportionate to the crime’s macroeconomic scale.

ID partially promotes the issue but demands urgent amendments to address its exclusion of NGOs from AML oversight, contrary to ID's evidence-based warnings about their vulnerability to financial crimes.  
This totally againsts with ID's position that AML rules must apply equally to all entities, given MONEYVAL's documented cases of NGOs laundering funds for terrorism.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as EU member states serving as de facto tax havens through lax trust regulations, which Herve Juvin identifies as central to systemic laundering risks.  
ID requests revisions to Article 4 to mandate public registries of NGO donors and beneficiaries, mirroring corporate beneficial ownership requirements.  
The issue remains inconsistent with ID's stance on capital controls, failing to acknowledge free movement of funds as the root enabler of cross-border laundering networks.

GUE_NGL strongly endorses the issue’s call to replace AML/CTF directives with directly applicable regulations, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to combatting financial crime through harmonized EU-wide standards.  
GUE_NGL completely approves the demand for a transparent methodology to identify high-risk third countries, emphasizing that excluding Saudi Arabia and tax havens from scrutiny fundamentally contradicts anti-corruption principles.  
GUE_NGL applauds the emphasis on addressing supervisory failures exposed by the Danske Bank scandal, noting this aligns with their 2019 manifesto priorities to dismantle banking sector impunity.  
GUE_NGL proposes accelerating the timeline for establishing centralized beneficial ownership registers to mitigate risks of further delays in tracing illicit flows.  
GUE_NGL strongly approves the issue’s critique of fragmented FIUs, urging immediate budgetary increases to ensure cross-border cooperation matches the scale of money laundering threats.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over significant gaps in the implementation of the EU’s anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing (AML/CTF) framework, particularly noting that many Member States failed to properly transpose the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive (4AMLD) by its June 2017 deadline, prompting infringement procedures by the Commission. It stressed urgency in meeting the 10 January 2020 deadline for transposing the Fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive (5AMLD), including establishing beneficial ownership registers, and highlighted risks of further delays. The resolution cited the Danske Bank case, involving over €200 billion in suspicious transactions, as emblematic of supervisory failures and criticized the rejection of a breach-of-law recommendation by national supervisors within the European Banking Authority (EBA). It underscored systemic weaknesses, including regulatory fragmentation, insufficient cross-border cooperation among Financial Intelligence Units (FIUs), and the need to consider replacing directives with directly applicable regulations to harmonize AML/CTF rules. The Parliament criticized the Commission’s February 2019 list of 23 high-risk third countries—including Afghanistan, Iran, and Saudi Arabia—which the Council rejected due to procedural flaws, and called for a transparent, autonomous methodology to identify such countries, free from diplomatic interference, while proposing a "grey list" akin to tax non-cooperative jurisdictions. It urged increased resources for AML enforcement, welcomed the EBA’s strengthened role, and emphasized the economic impact of money laundering, citing Europol estimates that 0.7–1.28% of EU GDP (€110–190 billion annually) is linked to illicit financial flows. The resolution also advocated for a potential EU-level supervisory body and improved coordination mechanisms to address cross-border threats.
